title: Fertile Ground ,  Life of Pi , and Soar Ultimate Frisbee : 10 things to do this week
body_text:
Explore new work, new events, and new options this week as spring warms up the world of entertainment. Check out a new event all about the art of manicures or see new theater, dance, and comedy shows at the Fertile Ground Festival. There’s also the first home game for Portland’s new Ultimate Frisbee team. Sure, you can’t do it all, but you can certainly give it a try.
ManiFest
Manicures have sure come a long way since the “you’re soaking in it!” days. The Nail Art community will gather in Portland this weekend for a celebration of creativity and artistic expression that shows itself proudly on your finger tips. View site-specific installation of nail art and talk to professionals about their craft.
Time-session admission 10 a.m.-4 p.m. and 4-10 p.m. Friday-Saturday, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Sunday, April 4-6, Union Pine, 525 S.E. Pine St.; $25 advance, $30 at door; mani-fest.me/.
Greater Portland Flute Society
Guest artist flutist Marco Granados is accompanied by pianist Kristy Moore in a concert of works by Astor Piazzolla, Enrique Granados, Carlos Guastavino, Edwin York Bowen, Walter Gieseking, and Marco Granados.
7 p.m. Friday, April 4, Eliot Hall Chapel, Reed College, 3203 S.E. Woodstock Blvd.; $20; gpfs.org/event.
Fertile Ground 2025
The Portland Theater Alliance’s annual city-wide festival showcases new work from area artists in various art forms, including theater, dance, comedy, and film. There’s far too much to mention in one blurb, but the opening day Friday includes a night of “small bites” theater by Audrey Block, E.M. Lewis, Lolly Ward and others, one-man show “Rasputin” by David Wagstaff, and interactive performance “Moments of Reckoning” by Nancy Campbell, Mishelle Apalategui, and Timothy Krause.
Visit the festival page for a complete list of events through April 19. Venues, times and ticket prices vary; fertileground.tix.page.
“Chronopolis: Crime in Time City”
This original circus noir, written and composed by Pete Irving and performed by Hot Damn Scandal, follows Charlie Burton through the streets of Chronopolis as he attempts to get to the bottom of a major disappearance of time from the city’s vaults. Expect live circus acts, contortion, juggling and more with a live soundtrack of original music.
8 p.m. Friday-Saturday, 4 p.m. Sunday, April 4-6, Alberta Rose Theater, 3000 N.E. Alberta St., tickets $28 advance, $35 at door; etix.com/ticket.
Soar Ultimate Frisbee match
This is not your dad’s game of Frisbee. Ultimate Frisbee is played a bit like football with two teams on the field trying to score points in the opposing teams end zone. Soar is Oregon’s new professional women’s team based in Portland. Chelsea Putnam, Soar’s head coach played and coached for the USA team and competed in Worlds in Taiwan in 2009. See the high-flying action at the team’s first home game this Saturday against Colorado’s Alpenglow at the U of O’s Portland campus.
2 p.m. Saturday, April 5, U of O in Portland, 2800 N.E. Liberty St., tickets $10 youth/student, $15 general; oregonultimatealliance.com.
“Surrounded in Darkness, Enfolded in Light”
In Mulieribus, the women’s vocal ensemble, presents a candle-lit concert featuring François Couperin’s “Trois Leçons de Ténèbres” (Three Lessons of Darkness). Originally composed for the nuns of the Royal Abbey of Longchamp in 1714.
7:30 p.m. Saturday, 4 p.m. Sunday, April 4-5, The Old Madeleine Church, 3123 N.E. 24th Ave.; tickets $15-$45; inmulieribus.org/2024-2025.
“Tiny Beautiful Things”
Magenta Theater presents a one-night special performance based on the bestselling book by Cheryl Strayed and adapted for the stage by Nia Vardalos. The show highlights the questions and answers submitted to the “Dear Sugar” advice column. Actors perform this staged reading with a bare minimum of rehearsal time and minimal sets.
7:30 p.m. Saturday, April 5, Magenta Theater, 1108 Main St., Vancouver; tickets $15; magenta.ludus.com.
“Life of Pi”
The Tony Award-winning stage adaptation of the Yann Martel novel offers an epic story of perseverance and hope. Expect lavish sets, world-class puppetry, and professional stagecraft.
Opens 7:30 p.m. Tuesday, April 8, Keller Auditorium, 222 S.W. Clay St.; continues various dates and times through April 13. Tickets start at $29.75; portland5.evenue.net.
UFO Northwest: How Washington State Spawned the Men In Black
On Aug. 1, 1947, the tragic crash of a B-25 bomber in Washington triggered an FBI investigation of “The Maury Island Incident.” Was it a northwest UFO sighting? The FBI’s records from 1947, which were sealed for decades, reveal Cold War fears, jurisdictional disputes, cover-ups, false confessions, a courageous FBI special agent, and the hands-on involvement of FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover. Hear the history of this story that helped shape the current UFO narratives as told by Steve Edmiston.
6 p.m. Thursday, April 10, Howard House, 750 Anderson St., Vancouver; free but reservation are requested; thehistorictrust.org/calendar/ufo-northwest.
“Shift Work: Queer Artists in Tectonic Times”
Multnomah Arts Center in southwest Portland presents the work of more than 50 regional artist that explore the emotional complexity of rapidly shifting social and political landscapes for LGBTQIA2S+ people.
Opening reception 6 p.m. Thursday, April 10. The show continues during gallery hours through May 10, Multnomah Arts Center, 7688 S.W. Capitol Highway; free; multnomahartscenter.org.
